Register.name: ah
Register.description: Accumulator. Cannot be accessed when using the REX.W instruction prefix. The prefixed is added (automatically by assemblers) when an operand contains a 64-bit register

Register.name: bh
Register.description: Base. Cannot be accessed when using the REX.W instruction prefix. The prefixed is added (automatically by assemblers) when an operand contains a 64-bit register

Register.name: ch
Register.description: Counter. Cannot be accessed when using the REX.W instruction prefix. The prefixed is added (automatically by assemblers) when an operand contains a 64-bit register

Register.name: rdx
Register.description: Data (commonly extends the A register)

Register.name: edx
Register.description: Data (commonly extends the A register)

Register.name: dx
Register.description: Data (commonly extends the A register)

Register.name: dh
Register.description: Data (commonly extends the A register). Cannot be accessed when using the REX.W instruction prefix. The prefixed is added (automatically by assemblers) when an operand contains a 64-bit register

Register.name: dl
Register.description: Data (commonly extends the A register)

Register.name: rip
Register.description: Instruction Pointer. Can only be used in RIP-relative addressing.

Register.name: eip
Register.description: Instruction Pointer. Can only be used in RIP-relative addressing.

Register.name: ip
Register.description: Instruction Pointer. Can only be used in RIP-relative addressing.

Register.name: cs
Register.description: Code Segment. Treated as if its base is 0 no matter what the segment descriptors in the GDT say.

Register.name: ds
Register.description: Data Segment. Treated as if its base is 0 no matter what the segment descriptors in the GDT say.

Register.name: ss
Register.description: Stack Segment. Treated as if its base is 0 no matter what the segment descriptors in the GDT say.

Register.name: es
Register.description: Extra Segment (used for string operations). Treated as if its base is 0 no matter what the segment descriptors in the GDT say.

Register.name: fs
Register.description: General Purpose F Segment. MSRs can change its base.

Register.name: gs
Register.description: General Purpose G Segment. MSRs can change its base.

Register.name: rflags
Register.description: Reserved Flags Register

Register.name: cr0
Register.description: Control Register 0. This is the only control register that can be written and read via 2 ways unlike the others that can be accessed only via the MOV instruction.

Flag.description: Protected Mode Enable

Flag.description: Cache disable

register.name: cr1
register.description: Control register 1. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr2
Register.description: Control Register 2. This control register contains the linear (virtual) address whcih triggered a page fault, available in the page fault's interrupt hander.

Register.name: cr3
Register.description: Control Register 3. This must be page aligned.

Register.name: cr5
Register.description: Control Register 5. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr6
Register.description: Control Register 6. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr7
Register.description: Control Register 7. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr8
Register.description:
Control Register 8. CR8 is used to prioritize external interrupts and is referred to as the task-priority register (TPR).
The AMD64 architecture allows software to define up to 15 external interrupt-priority classes. Priority classes are numbered from 1 to 15, with priority-class 1 being the lowest and priority-class 15 the highest. CR8 uses the four low-order bits for specifying a task priority and the remaining 60 bits are reserved and must be written with zeros.
System software can use the TPR register to temporarily block low-priority interrupts from interrupting a high-priority task. This is accomplished by loading TPR with a value corresponding to the highest-priority interrupt that is to be blocked. For example, loading TPR with a value of 9 (1001b) blocks all interrupts with a priority class of 9 or less, while allowing all interrupts with a priority class of 10 or more to be recognized. Loading TPR with 0 enables all external interrupts. Loading TPR with 15 (1111b) disables all external interrupts.
The TPR is cleared to 0 on reset.

Register.name: cr9
Register.description: Control Register 9. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr10
Register.description: Control Register 10. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr11
Register.description: Control Register 11. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr12
Register.description: Control Register 12. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr13
Register.description: Control Register 13. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr14
Register.description: Control Register 14. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: cr15
Register.description: Control Register 15. Reserved, CPU will throw a #ud exception when trying to access.

Register.name: ia32_efer
Register.description: The Extended Feature Enable Register (EFER) is a model-specific register added in the AMD K6 processor, to allow enabling the SYSCALL/SYSRET instruction, and later for entering and exiting long mode. This register becomes architectural in AMD64 and has been adopted by Intel. Its MSR number is 0xC0000080.

Flag.label: SCE
Flag.description: System Call Extensions

Flag.label: LME
Flag.description: Long Mode Enable

Flag.label: LMA
Flag.description: Long Mode Active

Flag.label: NXE
Flag.description: No-Execute Enable

Flag.label: SVME
Flag.description: Secure Virtual Machine Enable

Flag.label: LMSLE
Flag.description: Long Mode Segment Limit Enable

Flag.label: FFXSR
Flag.description: Fast FXSAVE/FXSTOR

Flag.label: TCE
Flag.description: Translate Cache Extension

Register.name: fs.base
Register.description:
MSR with the address 0xC0000100, contains the base address of the FS segment register. This is commonly used for thread-pointers in user code and CPU-local pointers in kernel code. Safe to contain anything, since use of a segment does not confer additional privileges to user code.
In newer CPUs, this can also be written with the WRFSBASE instruction at any privilege level.

Register.name: gs.base
Register.description:
MSR with the address 0xC0000101, contains the base address of the GS segment register. This is commonly used for thread-pointers in user code and CPU-local pointers in kernel code. Safe to contain anything, since use of a segment does not confer additional privileges to user code.
In newer CPUs, this can also be written with the WRGSBASE instruction at any privilege level.

Register.name: kernelgsbase
Register.description: MSR with the address 0xC0000102. Is basically a buffer that gets exchanged with GS.base after a swapgs instruction. Usually used to separate kernel and other use of the GS register.

Register.name: dr0
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr1
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr2
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr3
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr6
Register.description: Permits the debugger to determine which debug conditions have occurred. When an enabled debug exception is triggered, low order bits 0-3 are set before entering debug exception handler.

Register.name: dr7
Register.description: A local breakpoint bit deactivates on hardware task switches, while a global does not. Condition 00b means execution break, 01b means a write watchpoint, and 11b means a R/W watchpoint. 10b is reserved for I/O R/W (unsupported)

Register.name: xmm0
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm1
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm2
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. Register.description: A SIMD register. This register can be used to store four 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, or eight 32-bit single precision floating point numbers. The lower half maps onto the corresponding XMM register.
